Looks great to me! Just a few minor nits.

I can also fix those in the merge so feel free to leave as-is; I will fixup and merge tomorrow if you haven't made the fixups.
Added tests (while I was at it, moved OffsetRange and its Tracker to SDK since that'd be the third time I'd use it, including some pending code of mine where I use it in an integration test).

https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_MavenInstall/6950/

LGTM. If you prefer, I can fixup the one javadoc issue in merge; if you don't push I'll do so tomorrow.

The coveralls change seems weird. My change does not affect any of the files in which it reported changed coverage.
Coveralls is weird. It says SplittableProcessElementsEvaluatorFactory is basically not covered, but it is covered by SplittableParDo tests in direct runner.

This is a Jacoco configuration issue. All coveralls does is present the data, which is essentially available. I won't block anything on Coveralls.

To easily browse yourself, run `mvn jacoco:report`

@jkff -- I believe this is induced by our crazy test setup. The SDK tests are covered in the direct runner module, etc. The issue is that we have not asked jacoco to combine these things into one report.

I spent a few minutes trying to fix this using newer versions of plugins that claim to be able to do it, but stalled: https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/1800

+1. Looks like it only recognizes capital letters: `([A-Z][A-Z0-9]+-\d+)` which is what I had noticed not working in the past, and mis-remembered :). Thanks for clearing it up!

What's the threshold for a JIRA (which are fairly heavyweight)? This is basically "I cleaned up a test I noticed while working on another ticket" (though it did evolve from the original 1-character change) and I don't think that meets the bar.

The current threshold is "all changes need a JIRA" (note the github template makes this clear).

There is definitely a need for a `[codehealth]` tag or a `[trivial]` tag. We need to start this discussion.

But in general, I'd say if it has a nonzero change of causing flakes (e.g., affects any test code, pipeline structure, etc.) it needs some public justification that is on an Apache-managed property. We've had build breaks because someone upgraded a dependency with no explanation, and it's hard to know whether it's safe to rollback without understanding why the change was made.

This is especially crucial given how global Beam is -- people are off time zone and don't have everyone reachable instantaneously via chat.

R: @chamikaramj 

Re-opening https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/1848 as a new PR.

Added a unit test and removed the change in `wordcount.py`. Adding `WordCountOptions` work when `wordcount` is run only by itself but fails when running with `tox`. All tests after the wordcount test start requiring the `output` flag as defined in the wordcount options. This happens with or without the current change to the `pipeline_options`. We need to fix that later.
Thanks Rav!
Another related change: https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/1884

I'd say that requiring a JIRA issue for cleanups discourage code health (or, possibly, worse, encourage always folding such changes into other, unrelated PRs). For this PR I created and closed a ticket. I'll start a discussion on what to do in general. 

Of course justification for upgrading a dependency, which is a bigger change, should be in the commit itself... (commit messages should say why, not just what, as what can often be inferred from the code).
Let me rebase the PR

As for Write and its weird composite, I can explain it, but generally this is where things become tricky.. knowing when composites that are broken down into primitives to be executed by the Spark runner, would actually be a single transformation in Spark API (it's not directly translated because Beam has a different set of IO support, and a different approach and the runner should keep up with Beam).
I'm going to get green, fire off a postcommit, then merge. If  you'd like to fix up to preserve merge coherence you can, or I will squash when I merge, losing the history.
